contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "royal throne" may refer to his rule over the kingdom. Alternate translation: "ruled the empire" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
Here "name" represents the authority of the king. Alternate translation: "in the authority of" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
Speech coming out of the mouth is a metonym that represents speaking. Alternate translation: "As soon as the king said this" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: As soon as this sentence came out of the king's mouth

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "your eyes" is a metonym for sight, and sight is a metaphor representing his evaluation. Alternate translation: "if you evaluate me and I please you" or "if you are pleased with me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I am pleasing in your eyes

contextId.occurrenceNote: Writing something in the king's name represents writing it with his authority, or writing it as his representative. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Write ... in the name of the king

contextId.occurrenceNote: Writing something in the king's name represents writing it with his authority, or writing it as his representative. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: decree that has already been written in the king's name

contextId.occurrenceNote: Writing something in the king's name represents writing it with his authority, or writing it as his representative. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: wrote in the name of King Ahasuerus

contextId.occurrenceNote: The "city" represents the people living in it. Alternate translation: "the people of the city of Susa shouted and rejoiced" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the city of Susa shouted and rejoiced

contextId.occurrenceNote: Laying hands on people is a metonym for fighting against them. Alternate translation: "to fight their enemies" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: to lay hands on those who tried to bring disaster on them

contextId.occurrenceNote: Standing against people represents resisting their attack. Alternate translation: "No one could resist the attack of the Jews" or "No one could successfully fight against the Jews" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: No one could stand against them

contextId.occurrenceNote: Laying their hands on things represents taking them. Alternate translation: "took none of the plunder" or "did not take any of the plunder" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: laid no hands on the plunder

contextId.occurrenceNote: Laying their hands on things represents taking them. Alternate translation: "they did not take any of the valuables of the people they killed" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: they did not lay their hands on the valuables of those they killed

contextId.occurrenceNote: To impose a tax means to make people pay a tax. The land and coastlands represent the people living there. Alternate translation: "made the people living in the land and on the coastlands along the sea pay a tax" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: imposed a tax on the land and on the coastlands along the sea
